name: Yannis Smaragdakis
content: Yannis Smaragdakis Yannis Smaragdakis (also Ioannis Smaragdakis, Γιάννης Σμαραγδάκης) Professor (35%-time, also at Dedaub) Mailing address (shortened but valid): Dept. of Informatics, University of Athens, Ilisia, 15784, Greece Phone: +30 210 7275311 Email: yannis@smaragd.org (or smaragd@di.uoa.gr) Events: Current Service: while part-time, I am less likely to accept service duties. YouTube channel for my lab Teaching: Greece: Compilers (S11,S12,S13,S14,S15,S16,F17,S19,S20,S21,S22,S25); Analysis of Smart Contracts on Blockchain Platforms (S25); OO Languages and Systems/Advanced Programming Techniques (F10, F11, F12, F13, F14, F15, F17, F18, F19, F20, F21); Advanced Compilers and Static Analysis (S19, S20,S21,S22); Operating Systems (F17); Systems Programming (S14,S15,S16); SE (S11,S12,S13). US: SE (S09); OO Languages and Systems (F09, S09, S08, S07, F05, F04, F03, F02, F01); Graduate Seminar (S07, F08); Distributed Systems (F06, F07); Intro OO (F05, S05); Advanced OS (S04, S03, S02, S01, S00); Memory Management (F00). Research Programming languages and software engineering: Program analysis (static analysis, test generation, invariant inference, symbolic execution) Language mechanisms for abstraction (declarative languages, program generation, DSLs, modules and components, generics, extensible languages, multi-paradigm programming) Languages and tools for systems (programming models for concurrency, language support for distributed computing, memory management and program locality) Gratefully acknowledging funding by the ERC (Advanced grant, '24-'29), and the HFRI. (Very outdated) CV My Ph.D. students: Anastasis Antoniadis.. Sifis Lagouvardos.. Panagiotis Diamantakis. Ph.D. alumni: Brian McNamara, Eli Tilevich, Christoph Csallner, Shan Shan Huang, John Altidor, Kaituo Li, Aggelos Biboudis, George Balatsouras, George Kastrinis. i.e., creating classes by iterating over members of other classes. This work also includes a generalization of the concept of "variance" in generics/templates: a way to marry parametric and subtype polymorphism. In the 90s, I also worked (as an intern and a funded Ph.D. student) on the Intentional Programming (IP) project at Microsoft. Declarative languages: I am a late convert to declarative programming. An interesting direction is bounded, special-purpose declarative languages (e.g., for parallelism, or for GC-time computation). "Next-Paradigm Programming Languages: What Will They Look Like and What Changes Will They Bring?" (Onward! A Language for Heap Assertions at GC Time" (OOPSLA'10) "A New Java Runtime for a Parallel World" (PLDI'10 FIT) Program analysis and test generation for bug detection: the most recent work includes Residual Investigation: an approach that enhances static bug warnings with predictive dynamic analyses. My original work includes JCrasher and its followups, CnC and DSD-Crasher. JCrasher is a system for random testing of Java programs. CnC combines static checking (the ESC/Java system) with automatic test case generation. DSD-Crasher adds a dynamic invariant detection step to CnC. Finally, the ORM- modeling formalism allows efficient satisfiability checking and test data generation.
